header.rec_loc: The office of a charity called The Brix in Brixton, South London where both persons are employed
header.topics: Conversion of a space. Activities taking place in the building. Generating income. Marketing the business. Buying new furniture. Relationships with tenants and users. Birds. Maintenance. Fire escapes. Storage. Holiday cover and arrangements. Staffing arrangements and pay. Upcoming bookings.
header.conv_type: Discussing, explaining, inquiring, advising, requesting, anecdote telling

body.u: right so I'm gonna start it out now so so we can talk about the kinds of things you wanted to get my feedback on
right okay right well first and foremost like I said was talking about this erm er who who do you reckon would be the first person to contact?
about the conversion of this space?
yeah about the structural sort of possibilities cos if they then if they've gotta stay connected to these stud walls for some unknown weird reason then that sort of stops it going ahead
yeah
cos we can't go putting in any more supports it will be intrusive enough to have a space that's got these steels and just about saleable with those steels all the way through the room

yeah erm I erm I think it's very because I think that if we that a conversion of the building happened in the seventies and the eighties and that was definitely his work and he was in charge so there were two phases of works one in nineteen seventy-five seventy-six and then the next in nineteen eighty and then the works carried on between then and nineteen eighty-six nineteen eighty-seven
yeah

so erm and he was the architect for all of that work and that was the point at which they put the theatre in downstairs and these spaces upstairs were converted into those erm kind of little shed things

the little chicken wire sheds that we saw in that photograph out there so whether these struts are part of keeping the ceiling k part of keeping the roof up because we are actually in a what would've been a disused space

cos that's what steels was there to replace

the roof up above or erm

then that'd be weird and

that goes all the way through so that bit there will go has got a bit that then travels across that office and the next office

are in the space that we don't wanna touch anyway

to actually use erm I mean it's still a usable space you could set the room up anything like that and still be able to see they're not they're not that big that they're sort of gonna be a restrictive view for anybody it's not like having a a big concrete pillar or something in the in the theatre or whatever

for that for that price

which is basically we're only in

and that's only because they've got the the vast majority of er the business coming from them so I mean if we did it that way then seven hundred and fifty hours over the course of a year at thirty-six quid that's still twenty-seven grand

yeah yeah they'd be both happy with thirty to give her the hours that she wants

of of around fifteen hours a week maybe a little bit more give or take but I need to be able to rent it out for the lion's share of the days Monday through Friday nine till five

so it diminishes all possibility of being able to get an a bump up of of money I mean I wouldn't be able to get many more churches and stuff in which is also good money at the weekend

yeah but then on the other hand we must bear in mind that all of these people are erm temporary fixtures if we give them a space we don't have to give them a space forever so say for example if s if Krav Maga or something we should probably have all of these these er on a on a on a contract on a term contract

so that we give them six months or we give them a year and it's renewable after that time so we er you know we don't want to mess people about and and throw them out and have them on the streets but quite frankly they they they will up sticks as we know they will up sticks and disappear from one week to the next
yeah
if it suits them so therefore we should have contracts with them that allow us to say look I'm sorry we've changed our minds this is not working for us
mm

and and erm er and you know please review terminate and go away by extent which is the end of your term contract with us so rather than being arbitrary with people we we we do sort of say to them look this is for six months this is for a year and then at the end of the year we reserve the right to renegotiate
well the main set-up with erm the erm hall bookings more specifically Krav Maga at the minute they're on a recurring contract where we can stop them just as as easy as they can stop us

but the understanding I've got with them is that his price is based on a is he's been given a price for the next year so next April May sort of time we'll have to go through and renegotiate his his tariff that he's on cos it will have to go up a little bit

but then we could look at doing that and go right okay I'm gonna put your money up but I will give the security of a twelve-month fix so

at will really the only way to not have that kind of thing happen to you is have a formal lease

the deal the rent is set on one side the term is set on the other side and then that both gives you advantages and then perhaps you that that's when you know you've got your pyour price but if you want to have casual use and you want to be able to pull out when you need to

and you want to be able to disappear between one day and the next you have to accept that your landlord might want to put your rent up between one day and the next
yeah well what I was thinking about for this space

going back to that is basically giving it over to people like for this sort of erm this er un erm the dismantling of the erm town hall sort of thing

and people needing it and saying to them
